Merlina H. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Merlina is separated from her spouse and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Merlina owns & operates a a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Merlina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Merlina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Merlina is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Merlina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Irene Mae

texts.en:
Irene Mae R. is from the village of Purok Makugihon, Gimangpang, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 25 years old. Irene Mae is separated from her spouse and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Irene Mae owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Irene Mae has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Irene Mae joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Irene Mae is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Irene Mae from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: An

texts.en: K. An, 66, is a widow and lives with her son in the Takeo province. Her son is married already but, so far, her son still lives with her. Since 1980, she has been making and selling palm cakes in the village and is able to make about US$2 of profit a day. Her son, Sem Boren, is a construction worker. On average, he makes US$2 per day as well. K. An is asking for a loan of US$700 so that she can start a new business for her daughter in law. She wants her daughter to operate a grocery store. (K. An is pictured with her son)

loans.use: To operate a grocery store.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane B. is married and lives in the province of Rizal in the Philippines with her supportive husband Orlando, a tricycle driver. She has three children. All of the children are currently studying at high school and grade school. Mary Jane is a hard working entrepreneur engaged in selling native products. She has been in business working as an entrepreneur for almost 8 years. 

Mary Jane would like to receive a loan amounting 35,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory for selling the native products.   She is planning to purchase a variety of products such as native bags, accessories, and more supplies. She believes that having a larger variety of inventory will help her to retain her current customers as well as to attract new clients in the neighborhood.

A proud member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines since 2003, Mary Jane has been a dedicated member, having regular attendance to weekly center meetings and solid records in repayments on previous loans.

Her long-term goals are to purchase a new van so she can expand her business to the nearby town of Morong. By owning her own transportation, Mary Jane will save time and money in purchasing a greater variety of inventory as well as selling products in other villages. With her hard work, focus, and determination, Mary Jane is hopeful that her business of selling native products will continue to grow and will improve the overall standard of living for her entire family.

She is happy that her living condition is better than in the past because she could generate more income from the business. Mary Jane would like to send all the best wishes to all the lenders around the world who are sponsoring this loan. She hopes that they will support her again in the future.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products such as native bags, accessories, and more supplies.

loans.name: Rowena Pascua Group

texts.en:
Rowena P. is from the town of Lawy, Capas Tarlac. She is 28 years old. Rowena is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Rowena is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Rowena is just starting this business.

In 2010, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Ith

texts.en: Ith S., age 38, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in the business of grinding rice and producing rice wine at home. She earns an income of approximately US$ 3 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this business since 1987. Her husband sells palm juice and palm fruits, earning an income of US$ 4 per day. The standard of living has been improved since S. has been in her business and she wants to have a loan to expand this business. S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a machine to grind rice to produce rice wine. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a machine to grind more rices.

loans.name: Emily's Group

texts.en:
Emily D. is from the town of Cebu San Isidro. She is 39 years old. Emily is the group leader of a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emily D. group.

Emily is married and has 1 adult-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising ducks to produce and sell eggs. Emily has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emily joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock to raise & sell in future. Emily is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock to raise & sell in future. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Emily from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Khvan

texts.en:
Mrs. N. has been operating her own small business from her home for years. She is skilled in weaving palm leaves by hand and has done this since she was a single girl. She turns leaves into furniture and roofing material to sell for a profit. N. was married, but her husband died several years ago. She has two daughters; one is married and lives away from home and the other is single and a vegetable seller. 

N. depends on the income from her daughter, who sells vegetable in the market. Her daughter always needs to hire a taxi to deliver her vegetables to the market because she has no a vehicle. N. is taking out her loan to buy a motorcycle which will be used by her daughter to transport goods to and from her business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng Vouen, 32, is married and lives with his wife and three children in the Takeo province. He works to collect palm juice and refine it to palm sugar. On average, he makes $4 a day. His wife has a business selling desserts in the afternoon and porridge in the morning from her home. With this business, she is able to make $3 per day. 

Seng Vouen would like to create a new business so that his family can get more income to improve their standard of living. He will take this money to raise cows and resell them.

loans.use: Raise cows

loans.name: Khoan

texts.en: Khoan N. is single and resides with her family in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She is employed as a local primary school teacher, earning an income of approximately $2.50 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses. She has been with this job since 1990. Her standard of living has been improved since N. began this job, so she wants to have a loan to start a business. N. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase palm sugar for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy palm sugar for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Yoeurn Douk Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan includes twelve people who live in Sdok village in Takeo province. Mrs. Yoeurn D. is the village loan president who has been selected by all the members, who will each use their loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Yoeurn D. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Meng Che, owns a rice mill in the local village. The couple have 3 children, one of whom is an employee in a garment factory, while the other 2 are attending the local public school.

While the family works hard in their business, they would like to earn more income and improve their living conditions. Mrs. Yoeurn D. has therefore decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to re-sell.

loans.use: To buy more rice to re-sell

loans.name: Marites' Group

texts.en:
Marites E. is from the village of Burgos. She is 29 years old. Marites is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marites E..

Marites is married. To make a living, Marites owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling mobile phone credit loads in the local community. Marites has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately $200 a month from this activity.

In 2010, Marites joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marites is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Khsang

texts.en:
Mrs. Khsang H., 54, is a widowed mother caring for four children who are students in the local public school. She currently earns a living planting vegetable crops. All of her children also work by growing crops when they are not studying. One of her daughters is working in a restaurant. 

Khsang H. planted her crop a month ago, but her crop is not growing well. Because of this problem, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer that she will use to increase her crop yield. The rest of the loan she will use to repair her old house.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Yon

texts.en:
P. Yon is 45 years old and resides with her husband in the Takeo province. Since 2008, she has been growing vegetables and raising animals to earn a living and is able to make US$1 per day, while her husband is a construction worker earning on average US$3 per day. The couple have three children, two of whom are in school and one is a construction worker like his father.
P. Yon would like to take out a loan of US$1000 to re-build their pig cage and also raise more pigs.

loans.use: to rebuild their pig cage and raise pigs.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward A. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 45 years old. Edward is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edward owns and operates a general store, selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Edward has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately $150 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Edward joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edward has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Edward is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the store. This will be his 2nd loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new equipment and tools to expand the store

loans.name: Hongor

texts.en:
Hongor is 41 years old and lives with her husband and four children in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. She retails household products by herself, and her husband is a herder in the Tarialan soum. They have been living in their current home for seven years and their health is good. She has been operating her retail household product business since 2000. Originally, she worked with her brother at his counter, but in 2004 started working separately. Hongor built her own shop at the “Itgelt” market in 2008, and her business is healthy now. Her brother Hishigee supports her and her business, and he purchases inventory for her business.

Hongor is a decent person and she is good at accounting for her own products. She says, “I would like to work hard to buy a car for my family.” She is requesting 300,000 tugrug to purchase products in China.

loans.use: To purchase household products for resale.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C. is from the village of Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is 55 years old and married with seven school-age children. Elsa owns and operates a specialized retail store selling GANO products (which include food supplements and herbal coffee) in the local community. She's been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elsa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that she used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a loan of 11000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her shop.

loans.name: Mrs. Chhong Mam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan includes twelve members who all live in Sdok village in Takeo province. Mrs. Chhong M. is the village bank president and was selected by all the members. Each member of the group will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Chhong M. is a farmer who owns one-hectare of land on which she cultivates rice to support her family. She is a widow with three children, who all are enrolled in the local public school. However, this family tries to work hard in the field so they can earn more income. In order to improve the condition of her family's standard of living, Mrs. Chhong M. wants to breed pigs but she does not have enough money to buy it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy some piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy piglets for breeding.

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en:
Ruth P. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 50 years old. Ruth is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Ruth P.'s group.

Ruth is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ruth owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $65 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Ruth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Pav

texts.en: Pav C. H. is a 60 year old widow who resides with her child in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She sells charcoal and firewood in her village, earning approximately $6 a day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, including her child’s education. She has been with this business since 2002 and it has improved her standard of living, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. H. is requesting a loan of $500 to repair the truck she used to transport firewood and charcoal for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To repair the truck she uses to transport charcoal and firewood for sale.

loans.name: Luciana's Group

texts.en:
Luciana M. is from the village of Tubod. She is the leader of a two-member group at PMPC. While each of them will receive an individual loan, they will be collectively responsible for paying back the loan if the other member is delinquent or defaults.

Luciana is 50 years old and married. To make a living, she owns and operates a business making and selling baked goods in the local community. She's been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2001, Luciana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC and is now requesting a loan of 10000 PHP (her portion of this group loan) to purchase the raw ingredients needed to make her products. This will be her tenth loan from PMPC and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

(her

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make her baked goods.

loans.name: Oeur

texts.en:
Oeur M. is a 47-year-old village woman who worked as a rice farmer before she was married. Now she sells fish that she buys from her wholesale supplier and other fishermen. She runs her business in the market and is earning approximately $5 a day. She has a partner in her husband, who assists her in selling fish.

The humble couple has five children who are no longer in school and are working with their businesses. The fish is at an especially a low price this season; Oeur M. needs a loan to buy fresh fish to turn into fish paste to sell.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish to turn into fish paste to sell.

loans.name: Pedro Jr's Group

texts.en:
Pedro Jr C. is from the village of Pilitan. He is 39 years old. Pedro Jr is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Pedro Jr C..

Pedro Jr is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Pedro Jr plants and harvests rice for selling. Pedro Jr has been engaged in his business for over fifteen years and earns approximately $1415 every cropping season (every four months).

In 2010, Pedro Jr joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Pedro Jr is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Mrs. Thim Heal Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan comprises sixteen people who live in Sdok village in TaK. province. Mrs. Thim H. is a village bank president who has been selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purpose. 

She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Buos Yorng, is a trailer driver. To improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Thim H. decided to apply for a loan to buy a bicycle for her children to use to go to school. She will use the rest of the loan to buy a television and pay for electricity for her house. She has two children, both of whom are enrolled at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy a bicycle for her children to go to school

loans.name: Nergui

texts.en: Nergui is 29 years old and lives with her husband and their two children in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, or Mongolian nomadic tent. Nergui's husband works as a seasonal driver in a company, transporting sand and gravel from March to October.  They have been running a cell phone repair service and following utility trading business since 2007. Her husband attended a cell phone servicing course called “Mobiservice”. They are planning to cooperate with salespeople who sell cell phones and to establish a guaranteed repair service center in the future. There is a need to improve their equipment because the numbers of their competitors has been increasing. Nergui is a decent and very hardworking person. She says, “I would like to establish a shop, sell all type of cell phones, and create my own cell phone repair service center.” She is requesting a 500,000-tugrug loan to purchase a reader of the cell phone program (UFS-BB5).

loans.use: To purchase a cellphone reader program

loans.name: Korn

texts.en: Korn S., age 26, is married and resides with her children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has a child. She is engaged in selling charcoal at home in her village, earning approximately US $4 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially those for her children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2007. Her husband transports dirt to fill out the land for people’s houses in the province, earning an income of US $4 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. S. is requesting a loan of US $200 to purchase more charcoal for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for sale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita N. is a 39-year-old woman, married and blessed with seven children. She and her husband work together to raised their big family. They are currently living at Taghangin, Morong Rizal, Philippines. She is also a woman of good faith to conquer all challenges to achieve family dreams. 

Nenita’s main goal is to build a sustainable business to meet the needs of her seven children; she was thus encouraged to join ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines, in 2004. The previous loans she received from ASHI were carefully invested in her variety store. Since then, the business has been performing well and earning her sufficient profit. She is grateful that she has been able to educate her children using proceeds from her business as she continues to expand. Nenita needs a loan to help boost her business for increased profit making.

She runs a variety store. She started her variety store through her initiative of dealing with customers. She wants to continue her business. She is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000 to use for additional capital to improve her business and her income. Specifically, the money will use to purchase five sacks of rice, charcoal, sugar, canned goods, cigarettes, fabric conditioner, and other inventory for her variety store. 

She dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to another village. Her seven children are her inspiration to pursue her variety store. She now feels very happy with the service of ASHI and KIVA. It gives them a big chance to pursue their family dreams. She hopes that they continue the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead.

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of the Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her variety store.

loans.name: Mrs. Vanthoeun Em Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan includes 15 people who live in Trapeang Young village in Takeo province. Mrs. Vanthoeun E. is the village bank president who was selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. She is a weaver in lthe ocal village and her husband, Mr. Sorphorn NhoE., is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow rice to support his family. In addition, he is a construction laborer. In order to expand their business, Mrs. Vanthoeun E. decided to ask for a loan to buy more silk for weavI.. She is the mother of three children. Two of the children are enrolled in local public school. The other child is too small to school or work.

loans.use: To buy more silk for weaving

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en: Tsetsegmaa is 53 years old and lives with her three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Since Tsetsegmaa hurt her leg last December, her oldest daughter has been running her business. Her youngest daughter goes to secondary school in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Since they started their second-hand products trading business, their quality of life has improved. Because of their hard work and determination, they have been able to buy a plot of land with a house and yard. They also bought a car in December.  She would like to ensure that her family is financially secure and able to pay the expenses of her youngest daughter until she graduates secondary school and finds a job. During the day, Tsetsegmaa has been operating her second hand products trading business at the central market since 2008.  Previously, she had worked as a shoemaker for 23 years, and Tsetsegmaa is a professional shoemaker.  She has been planning to continue stabilizing her business and to rent a counter for a food trading business at the new trading center. Her oldest daughter will run the second hand products business separately. Tsetsegmaa is an open person and says, “First, I would like to heal my leg and be healthy.” She is requesting a 2,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase six packages of inventory for her business. One package of inventory has an average cost of 200,000 – 400,000 tugrugs.

loans.use: To purchase six packages of inventory for her business

texts.ru: Хамдамов Шокирджон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 43 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Основным источником его дохода является растениеводство. Он берет землю в аренду, засеивает пшеницу и кортофель. После того как получает урожай, продает на рынке. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 10 лет. Сейчас посевной сезон и клиент хочет приобрести семена и удобрение. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Это поможет ему получить хороший урожай, что привлечет новых клиентов и без остатка реализовать свою продукцию.
texts.en:
Shokirdjon H. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 43 years old, married and has 5 children. His primary source of income is agriculture. He leases land, plants wheat and potatoes. Then, he sells the harvest at the market. Shokirdjon has been involved in this business for over 10 years. Because now is the planting season, the client wants to obtain seeds and fertilizers. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers. This will help him get a good harvest, which will attract new customers, allowing Shokirdjon to sell all of his product.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

She managed to grow and develop her venture and presently, she has 25,000 Grivnyas worth of merchandise. Her monthly income amounts to 10,000 Grivnyas.

Olga believes a loan of 9,800 Grivnyas will help her diversify assorted merchandise and attract new potential customers as a result. She is very organized and responsible. She can always give a sober evaluation of a situation and make a wise decision having calculated costs and profit. We believe Olga will efficiently use the current loan, using it to benefit further expansion of her successful trade.

Alla is married with two sons. She is a market entrepreneur from Mukachevo, Western Ukraine, where she sells women’s purses, backpacks, and bags in a marketplace next to the local bus station. Alla owns a well-equipped vending facility. She launched this business six years ago and currently has 30,000 Grivnyas invested in business.

Alla is hoping to use this loan for 6,500 Grivnyas to increase her assorted merchandise and grow her sales as a result. She believes financial assistance will help her keep her head over water in terms of the challenging economic recession. She is one of many small entrepreneurs who are struggling with staying afloat business-wise in Ukraine.

loans.name: Lelia's Group

texts.en:
Lelia D. is from the village of Talic. Lelia is the leader of a three-member loan group at PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lelia is 56 years old and married. To make a living, Lelia owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products in the local community. She's been engaged in her business for over twelve years.

In 2008, Lelia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC that she used to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital. She requested a second loan of 7000 PHP (her portion of the group loan) to use in the same way. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Sobitdjon

texts.en:
E. Sobitdjon is 50 years old and married with three children. He is a small entrepreneur who sells different kinds of foodstuff, like candies, cookies, preserved food, soft drinks, juice, tea, and many other items in the grocery store he built many years ago. Today, Sobitdjon is requesting a loan of 13,000 TJS to increase his stock. He is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices, and push every once and awhile to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. One of his dreams is that his children progress by means of their studies, for which he is doing all the best. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase foodstuff to expand his range of goods.

loans.name: Davronbek

texts.en:
Davronbek M. is a successful father and dedicated husband and together with his wife he has a little kid. Davronbek began a small grocery store two years ago with a small amount of savings that he had earned as a carpenter. He was assisted by his father who helps him with serving his clients. Today, his clientele has grown greater and his grocery become more popular. He is asking for a loan so that he may expand the variety of goods that are sold in his store. Davronbek is very grateful to everyone who is helping him to achieve successes in his business with this loan.

loans.use: To buy foodstuff to increase his range of goods.

loans.name: Helyn

texts.en:
Helyn C. is from the village of Damulog , Bukidnon. She is 35 years old and married with three school-age children. Helyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Helyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Helyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that she used to purchase additional products to sell. She requested a new loan of 11000 PHP to invest in expanding the business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her store.

loans.name: Mukarama

texts.ru: Нормуминова Мукарама проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 41 год. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Домохозяйка, но основным видом деятельности и основным источником дохода её семьи является растениеводство. Она выращивает и продает оващи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Mukarama N. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 41 years old, married and has 5 children. She is a homemaker, but her family's main business and primarily source of income is agriculture. Mukarama grows and sells vegetables. She has been involved in this business for 6 years. She is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Hikoyatullo

texts.en: Hikoyatullo Y. is 29 years old. He is married and has the business of baking “lepeshka,” the national bread. Hikoyatullo is the main breadwinner in the family. He believes that this business is profitable and is not subject to seasonality. He gets up early and bakes the lepeshka and bread so that people have fresh bread on their tables for breakfast. All the input materials like the flour, salt and yeast, he purchases in the local market. Now due to high demand, Hikoyatullo wants to increase the number of breads he can make, so he requests 4700 Somoni. The loan will be spent on flour and on coal for baking the “lepeshka.” Hikoyatullo deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him. More about Tajikistan Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing flour for baking the national bread, “lepeshka”

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
Lhagvsuren lives with her four children and husband in Tuv Aimag around Ulaanbaatar. She and her family run a meat stand they started in 2008. In just those years, their business has done very well. She has many returning customers. The business has increased 10 times in those years and they were even able to get a car and build a building inside their fence. 

Lhagvasuren is 50 years old and her children are all in school. The girls are 24 and 19, and the boys are 22 and 15. One of her children is in college and will graduate this year. They pay for school tuition with the money from the business and she has three more children. 

She wants a loan so that she can by meat in bulk as that will help her increase her business. Lhagvsuren hopes one day that her business will grow enough that they will be able to build their own store. She is humble, pleasant to be around and also a diligent, hard worker.

loans.use: To purchase meat in bulk to help her increase her business

loans.name: Gulzamon

texts.ru: Бутаева Гулзамон проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 48 лет. Замужем, имеет 8 детей. Муж, на заработках в Росии. Сама Гулзамон более 15 лет занимается животноводством. Она откармливает и продает скот. В этом ей помогают дети. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Gulzamon B. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 48 years old, married and has 8 children. Her husband is working in Russia. Gulzamon has been involved in animal husbandry for over 15 years. She raises and sells livestock. Her children help her with this business. Gulzamon is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock, in order to increase livestock quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma P. is from the village of Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 25 years old. Elma is single. To make a living, Elma runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Elma has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Elma from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Duong

texts.en:
Mrs. C. is a young mother blessed with a young child who is not yet enrolled in school. She has a partner in her husband, who works driving a taxi for income. C. currently works as part of the massage staff in a club located in Siem Reap province, earning a specific salary of $90 per month. 

C. always finds it hard travelling to work because she doesn’t have a vehicle. She hopes to own a motorcycle but she has no money to buy one. Recently she was encouraged by her nearby neighbor to pursue a loan via HKL. So she decided to apply for a loan of $1200 in order to purchase a new motorcycle which will enable her to ride to her work location.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle.

loans.name: Askarova Patma`s Group

texts.ru:
Аскарова Патма является лидером и инициатором создания данной группы солидарности. Ей 42 года, замужем и мать 4 детей: по два сына и дочери. Супруг клиента занимается сельским хозяйством, а именно выращивает культуры на собственном земельном наделе. Старшие дети работают отдельно от семьи, младшие двое школьницы. На данный момент клиент готовится к весеннему посеву, закупает семена картофеля для посева и минеральные удобрения и кредит будет использован для этих нужд. 

Шайыргуль является казначеем этой группы, также очень активный участник группы. Ей 50 лет, замужем.  У нее 6 детей: 2 сына и 4 дочери. Вместе с супругом она занимается выращиванием картофеля. Изначально они выращивали табак, однака из за низкой рентабельности продукта, переквалифицировались на картофель. Кредит будет использован для закупа 500 кг семян картофеля. В будущем клиент планирует взять в арендуземлю и увеличить таким образом посевную площадь. 

Айсарахан, 35 лет. Она замужем и воспитывает 4 детей. Все 4 дети школьного возраста. Ее супруг в данное время находится в России, работает поваром.   Она занимается откормом и реализацией животных.  Сейчас она откармливает корову, теленка и одну стельную корову. Также наравне с этим бизнесом, она выращивает технические культуры, в том числе картофель. Кредит будет использован для закупа семян картофеля. 

Парманов Анарбай единственный мужчина в данной группе. Человек очень волевой и работающий очень много, чтобы обеспечить свою семью наилучшим, что возможно. Он женат и воспитывает 3 детей. Его супругу крестьянка. Он вместе с остальными членами семьи возделывает землю и выращивают картофель. Также он дома держит скот. Кредит будет использован для закупа семян картофеля и минеральных удобрений.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.
texts.en:
Patma A. is the leader and initiator behind the creation of this group. She is 42 years old, married and is a mother of 4 children: two sons and two daughters. Patma’s husband is involved in agriculture; specifically, he grows plants on their own plot of land. The oldest children work away from the family, and the youngest two are school students. Currently, the client is preparing for the spring planting season, purchasing potato seeds for planting and mineral fertilizers, and will use this loan for these needs. Shayirgul is the treasurer of this group and is also a very active participant in the group. She is 50 years old, married and has 6 children: 2 sons and 4 daughters. Together with her husband, she is involved in growing potatoes. At first, they grew tobacco, but due to the low profitability of the product, they transitioned to potatoes. The loan will be used to purchase 500 kg of potato seeds. In the future, the client plans to lease land and this way increase their planting area. Aysarahan is 35 years old. She is married and is raising 4 children. All 4 children are of school age. Her husband is currently in Russia, working as a cook. Aysarahan is involved in raising and selling livestock. She is currently raising a cow, calf and one heifer. Also, along with this business, she grows industrial crops, including potatoes. The loan will be used for the purchase of potato seeds. Anarbay P. is the only man in this group. He is a very strong-willed person, who works a lot in order to provide his family with the best that is possible. He is married and is raising 3 children. His wife works in agriculture. Anarbay, together with the other family members, prepares the soil and grows potatoes. He also keeps livestock at home. The loan will be used for the purchase of potato seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of potato seeds

loans.name: Dairiimaa

texts.en:
Dairiimaa is 57 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Mongolian countryside of Tosontsengel province. For the past 20 years Dairiimaa has been making and selling boots. Five years ago her children began to run the business with her. Because they can’t find a building to move the business into Dairiimaa taught her daughters a how to make the boots so they can do it out of their home.  They make good work boots for the herders in the countryside since they are the main source of business.

With this loan Dairiimaa will buy materials for the boots (sable fur, leather, and other needed materials) and also because of winter conditions needs money to buy feed for their livestock.   Dairiimaa and her family have been living in their fence for 30 years. Her 66-year-old husband doesn’t work, and is on pension. Their grown children live with them to help run the business.

loans.use: To purchase materials for making boots

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim L. is 51 years old and lives in Chhoeng Chhorvin village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder and her husband, Mr. Ngorn Nut is a farmer who owns a two hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to support themselves.

In the rice field, they have some problems because the soil is infertile.  In order to improve the farm, Mrs. Sim L. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan money, she would like to buy hoses and plastic to protect the rice field.

She has three children, one of whom is a farmer, another a duck breeder, and the other a student at a local public school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Jose-Ann

texts.en:
Jose-ann D. is from the village of Don Carlos Bukidnon. She is 27 year-old single woman. Jose-ann owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She's been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

Jose-ann joined HSPFI this year to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting her first loan from HSPFI for 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in her store.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea S. is a widow woman and a humble citizen living in Siem Reap, a province of Cambodia. She has five single kids and one married kid. To help with feeding the family, one of her daughters works preparing rooms in a hotel.  

To earn a living, Chea S. owns a store inside the market where she sells a variety of wares to people who come to purchase anything in the market. Recently she has sold nearly all her inventory so she wants to resupply her store. Due to Chea S.'s lack of capital, she requested a loan to be used to increase the large number of items that she sells.

loans.use: To increase the large number of items she sells.

loans.name: Nen

texts.en:
Nen L. is 40 years old and married and lives with six of her children in the Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make about $1 each day and are supported by three children working in the garment factory. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has also been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, including Nen L..

Nen L. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. This will allow her children to save even more.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Chek

texts.en:
Chek S. is 31 years old, married, and resides with her four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She is a housewife staying at home to look after children and the household chores. Her husband operates his three-wheel vehicle to transport workers at the garment factory. By doing so, he is able to cover his family expenses, including their children’s education. Their standard of living has been improved since S.’s husband started this business so S. wants to have a loan to expand his business.

S. is requesting $1000 to buy a new motorbike and a trailer. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike with a trailer attached.

loans.name: Chhen

texts.en:
Chhen H. is 53 years old, married, and resides with her five children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has a business selling charcoal from home in her village and earns approximately $5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially her children’s education. She has been with this business since 1987 and her husband sells firewood, earning an income of $4 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since H. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand it.

H. is requesting a loan of $300 to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

H. is pictured above with her husband.

loans.use: To repair her house.

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: The photo shows Mrs. Kong R., 48, a rice farmer. She has been growing rice since 1995, a skill she learned from a grandparent who died of senility years ago. She is married to Oun Phom, 49, who works with her on the farm. This old couple has given birth to nine childR.. Three are married and the others are single and are studying or working. Kong R. lacks some farming supplies and is looking for assistance in order to plant dry season rice.

loans.use: To buy supplies for planting dry season rice.

loans.name: Charlita

texts.en:
Charlita T. is from the village of  Kadingilan, Bukidnon. She is a 50 year-old widow with one school-aged child. Charlita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She's been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Charlita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which she used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new and second loan of 8000 PHP to use for the same purpose. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 33 years old and married with an eleven year-old child in school. She's a farmer near Nkubu in Eastern Kenya. She's been poultry farming for just one year. She previously ran a restaurant but now sells eggs at the local market. She says that the main challenge to her business is the high cost of feeds.

She requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 70,000 to purchase more chickens, after completing a previous loan for Kes. 45,000. She says that these loans from Juhudi have helped her realize her dream of becoming a poultry farmer and that the extra income she'll earn will help her raise her family's standard of living. In the future, she says her target is to have 3000 layers (for eggs) and maybe even some broilers (to sell for meat).

loans.use: To expand her poultry farm.

loans.name: Daya Pertiwi Group

texts.en:
"GUSTI AYU S. (0) is a 32-year-old woman living in the town of TEGAL CANGKRING.  GUSTI AYU is the group leader of a 15-member group loan offered by MUK.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is DAYA PERTIWI (MUK-0006).

GUSTI AYU is married and has 2 very young children.  To make a living, GUSTI AYU owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale.  GUSTI AYU has been engaged in this business for over 4 years.

In 2008, GUSTI AYU joined MUK to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  GUSTI AYU is requesting a loan from MUK for the first time. She is now requesting a loan of 1,700,000 IDR which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future.  This will be the 2nd loan taken out by the borrower from MUK.  GUSTI AYU plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.


About MUK:

The mission of Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) is to assist small businesses in Bali by providing training, business consultation, and loans thereby helping the owners and their families improve their everyday lives.





GUSTI AYU S. (0) merupakan 32 tahun wanita.  Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota TEGAL CANGKRING.  GUSTI AYU adalah pemimpin kelompok sebuah kelompok peminjam yang terdiri atas 15 anggota.  Meskipun setiap anggota kelompok menerima pinjaman perorangan, mereka semua bertanggung jawab untuk mengembalikan pinjaman rekan anggota kelompok mereka jika ada yang menunggak atau gagal membayar.  Nama resmi kelompok peminjam ini adalah DAYA PERTIWI (MUK-0006).


Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual.  GUSTI AYU sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 4 tahun.  0  Dalam 2008, GUSTI AYU bergabung MUK untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan  -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis.  GUSTI AYU meminta pinjaman untuk pertama kalinya dari MUK.    Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 1,700,000 IDR.


Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 2nd pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari MUK.


Tentang MUK:

Misi Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) adalah untuk membantu usaha kecil di Bali dengan memberikan perlatihan, konsultasi bisnis, dan pinjaman uang, dengan demikian membantu pemilik usaha dan keluarga mereka memperbaiki hidup sehari-hari.


  "

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in future

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly S. is 46 years old, married, and resides with her four children in Kompong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She has a business selling furniture made from wood and earns approximately $7 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially her children’s education. She has been with this business since 2000 and her husband is a teacher for a public primary school, earning an income of  $2.50 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. started her business so she wants to have a loan to expand it. 

S. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase more wood to make more furniture to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva. 

S.'s sons are pictured here.

loans.use: To buy wood to make more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Mrs. Heang T. weaves rattan cupboards to sell. She sells her finished products to buyers who come directly to her house. She makes many sets of rattan before selling out. Her retailers need to wait a week or a few weeks in advance. She also orders baskets from the other villagers and sells them to make additional income. Her husband helps her pick up rattan to sell door-to-door in the village. Recently, Heang T. received orders from her customers, but her products are not sufficient to fill them. So she would like to request a loan in order to buy rattan products from other weavers to satisfy the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To buy rattans products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make snacks and other delicacies.

loans.name: Romel

texts.en:
Romel C. is from the village of Kadingilan, Bukidnon. He is a 25 year-old single man. Romel owns and operates a  taxi business for local community members. He's been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Romel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase materials that he needed to provide his service. He is requesting a new, second loan of 8000 PHP to further invest in expanding the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand his taxi business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy chickens for poultry farming.

loans.name: Archie

texts.en:
Archie N., 29, is from Labo, Ozamiz City. Archie is married and has no dependents. He owns and operates an internet café with 7 computers. Archie established his business over a year ago and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month. 

Recently Archie joined PMPC to access financial services and to help improve his living conditions. Archie is applying for a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to upgrade his computer system. He wishes to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to upgrade his internet computer system

loans.name: Gnek

texts.en:
To earn a living, Mrs. C. wakes up every morning and goes to the farms and market. She buys many kinds of farm products such as fresh vegetables, cooking ingredients, fruit, etc. She then hurries to bring them to sell at retail to people living in her village.

C. also relies on the proceeds from her husband’s business, the making and selling of wooden beds.

C. has four children; one is married and the other three are single.

C. will use half of her loan to increase her inventory and the rest to buy wood supplies and materials for her husband to make beds.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Lea Marietta

texts.en:
Lea Marietta G. is from the village of Aguada, Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental. She is 46 years old. Lea Marietta is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lea Marietta owns and operates a business venture, food vending. Lea Marietta has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

 In 2010, Lea Marietta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.Lea Marietta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional meat and ingredients for her food vending. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Lea Marietta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

 About PMPC:
 Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Food Vending and Retailing

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
Nieves G. is from the village of Kibawe, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Nieves is married and has seven adult-aged children. To make a living, Nieves owns and operates a business selling used clothing (or ukay ukay), and sometimes she also sells specialty homemade food products like banana chips in the local community. Nieves has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $100 a month from these activities.

In 2009, Nieves joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nieves has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be her 2nd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to further improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Kadiatu

texts.en:
Kadiatu C. sells cooking condiments at the central market, Bo, and has been in this business for twenty-two years now.

She is married to a trader who also trades in foodstuffs. She has ten dependents. She has spent most of her lifetime in her business.

Kadiatu wants to increase her profit margin by purchasing additional stock. She hopes to use the proceeds to support her kids' schooling and to start construction of their house on their recently purchased land.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Abdel - Aziz

texts.en: Abdel Aziz is a 47-year-old married man and father of three children who still go to school. For the past 12 years he has owned a legal office in a court to finalize all the legal papers and documents. Over the years, thanks to his business income, Abdel has been able to meet his children's needs. Today, he is asking to borrow $700 to buy a new photocopier machine needed to continue his work properly.

loans.use: To buy a new photocopier machine

loans.name: Im

texts.en: Im C., age 30, owns and operates a handicraft business whose main activity is making rattan cupboards and wooden beds. She sells her finished products to the middlemen who come to order directly from her home. She has a partner in her husband, who is skilled at making rattan and bed products by hand. The couple has given two school-aged children who are dependent on their income. Im has used up all of her raw materials and so is asking for a loan to purchase more rattan and plank to construct more cupboards and beds to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more rattan and plank to construct cupboards and beds.

loans.name: Roland

texts.en:
Roland Tarawallie owns a shop at the back of the central market in Bo. He sells various cooking items both wholesale and retail and has operated this business for twenty years.

He is married and has 10 dependents, four of whom are his children. One of the sons usually helps in the business. His wife is also a trader.

Roland seeks to import more products (food items) from Guinea. He has a very good group credit history and used to be the leader of a solidarity group.

He hopes to use the proceeds to educate his children and to build a house.

loans.use: To import food items from Guinea

loans.name: Zafardjon

texts.ru: Донияров Зафарджон проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 25 лет. Женат, не имеет детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Зафарджон занимается животноводством. Он откармливает и продает крупно- рогатый скот. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 8 лет. В этом ему помогает жена. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота. Зафарджон хочет увеличить количество скот. Он намерен разводит крупно- рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мясо.
texts.en:
Zafardjon D. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 25 years old, married and has no children. His wife is a homemaker. Zafardjon is involved in animal husbandry. He raises and sells cattle. Zafardjon has been involved in this business for over 8 years. His wife helps him with it. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle. Zafardjon wants to increase his livestock quantity. He intends to raise cattle in order to resell it for meat.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Doch

texts.en: Mr. Doch S. is a 56-year-old married man and father. He owns a motorbike that he uses to pick up passengers for a profit. He always operates around the market and over-crowded places. Through his business, he is able to make about $4 each day to manage his family's expenses. (He was busy providing his service when the photo was taken, so his wife is pictured instead.) His wife stays at home to do housework and also helps her daughter sell groceries in the market. Doch S. is taking out his loan to purchase furniture to decorate his house. With any remaining cash from his loan he will decorate his taxi.

loans.use: To decorate his house

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  sept femmes du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Noukoula de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et  des céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 8 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz) et  quelques paquets  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes à Noukoula et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
All seven women from the Benkadi group are married. On average they are 40 years of age with four children, and live in traditional households in the Noukoula neighborhood of Konobougou, in the Baouréli prefecture of the 4th administrative region of Mali. These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, for the most part culinary condiments and cereals. Having fully repaid their four previous loans, the women from the Benkadi group are now requesting a fifth group loan. They will use it to buy eight tons of cereal (beans, millet, corn, fonio, rice) and a few packages of culinary condiments. They get their supplies mainly from local producers and wholesalers, and sell their products at the Konobougou market, for cash or on credit, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 30,000 FCFA each, which will be used to increase their working capital and contribute to family expenses regarding food, children’s education and healthcare.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred K. owns a small store at the central market in Bo where he sells used clothing. He is married and his wife is also engaged in business. He has been in the clothing business for the past ten years.
