He has five dependents, two of whom are his kids. He has spent most of his time in this business since he dropped out of school.

By way of expansion Alfred wants to buy more stock that will increase his profit margin and which will enable him to start his building project on a piece of land he recently bought.

loans.use: To buy used clothing to resell.

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Noukoula de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et de l’habillement.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  Danaya sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires pour constituer un important stock de concentrée de tomates, d’oignons, de sounbala, de cubes maggies, d’huiles alimentaires, du gombo, des variétés de feuilles séchées. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement à Bamako et sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles effectuent leurs ventes à Noukoula et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui servira à subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants, à la santé et le reste, réinvesti dans les affaires.
texts.en:
All four women from the Danaya group are married. On average they are 45 years of age with three children, and all live in traditional households in the Noukoula neighborhood of Konobougou, in the Baouréli prefecture of the 4th administrative region of Mali. These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, for the most part culinary condiments and clothing. Having fully repaid their four previous loans, the women from the Benkadi group are now requesting a fifth group loan. They intend to use it to buy large quantities of food condiments, and create a sizable stock supply of tomato paste, onions, sounbala (spicy seasoning), Maggi cubes, vegetable oil, gombo, and various dried herbs. They mainly get their supplies from local producers and wholesalers and also in Bamako. They then sell their products in Noukoula and at the Konobougou market, for cash or on credit, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 25,000 FCFA each, which will be used to contribute to family expenses regarding food, children’s education and healthcare, the remainder being reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 43-year-old married man with 4 young kids. He is the only one to support his family with his business. He has been working in water refining for the past 13 years. And in 2009, he opened his own shop after seeing a need for such services in the region. Today, Hussein is requesting a loan of $1,000 to add more decor to his shop, in addition to buying water bottles for his work, in order to develop his business and make a good income.

loans.use: To add more decor to his shop in addition to buying water bottles

loans.name: Mayram

texts.ru: Меликова Майрам проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 52 года. Замужем, имеет одного сына. Муж пенсионер. Сын работает грузчиком. Сама Майрам занимается животноводством. Она разводит мелкий рогатый скот. Кредит берет для закупа коровы. Майрам хочет приобрести дойную корову и в дольнейшим продавать молоко.
texts.en:
Mayram M. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 52 years old, married and has one son. Her husband is retired. Son works as a stevedore. Mayram is involved in animal husbandry. She raises small livestock. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of a cow. Mayram wants to purchase a dairy cow and subsequently sell milk.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Horonya Group

texts.fr:
Les 4 femmes du groupe Horonya sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Noukoula de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et  des céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Horonya sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, quelques  sacs de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz) et une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes en ambulant à Noukoula et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12.500FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
All four women from the Horonya group are married. On average they are 45 years of age with three children, and all live in traditional households in the Noukoula neighborhood of Konobougou, in the Baouréli prefecture of the 4th administrative region of Mali. These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, for the most part culinary condiments and cereals. Having fully repaid their four previous loans, the women from the Horonya group are now requesting a fifth group loan. They intend to use it to buy a few bags of cereal (beans, millet, corn, fonio, rice), and a large quantity of food condiments. They mainly get their supplies from local producers and wholesalers and also in Bamako. They then sell their products as itinerant vendors in Noukoula and at the Konobougou market, for cash or on credit, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 12,500 FCFA each, which will be used to bolster their working capital and contribute to family expenses regarding food, children’s education and healthcare.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products

loans.name: Chann Kaev Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Chann K. is 56 years old and a married woman who lives in Prey Chambak village, Takeo province. She is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by AMK. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes: to purchase supplies, equipment and other items to support their businesses.
 
Mrs. Chann K. is a silk weaver who can make a small income to support her family. In order to increase her income and improve her family's standard of living, she now wants to enlarge her business. Thus, she is now requesting a loan of 500,000 KHR from AMK to purchase more silks for weaving. 

Her husband, Mr. Chi Nget, is a laborer and earns a small salary. This couple has four children, one of whom is a laborer, another is a silk weaver, and the other two are students in the public school.

loans.use: To purchase more silks

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred K. is a businessman who sells used clothing (caps) and owns two motorbikes that operate for commercial purposes.

He is married and his wife helps in the business. He has four kids, all in primary school. He has been in this business for four years.

In order to respond to his kids' schooling needs and to acquire a piece of land, Alfred is seeking a loan to buy more stock, thereby increasing his profit.

loans.use: To buy caps to sell

loans.name: Wesley

texts.en:
Wesley is 34 years old and married with two children, ages four and two, one of whom is in school. He is a dairy farmer near Litein in Western Kenya. He's been farming for three years and sells his milk through the Kenya Cooperative Creameries. He says that the main challenge to his business is providing enough feed from his small farm for his cow.

Wesley already completed a previous loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo, and requested this loan for 70,000 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the loan will provide extra income for his family and he'll be able to pay his school fees. In the future, he would like to get a dairy cow that could produce up to 20 liters a day.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Imane

texts.en: Imane has worked as a home-based hairdresser for the past 15 years. She receives clients at her home, where she has prepared a special room for this purpose and she is well known in her area. She has 2 kids and she cooperates with her husband in the household and in raising her children. Today, Imane is requesting a loan of $1,200 to improve the decor of her salon and buy specially designed barber chairs that will be more comfortable for the clients.

loans.use: To improve the decor of her salon and buy specially designed barber chairs

loans.name: Niètaga Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Niètaga sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Dioni de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, de céréales, des savons, des pommes de terre, du poisson séché etc.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Niètaga sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, trois tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio) et des colis  de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes à Dioni et au marché de Konobougou, généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 17.500FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
All ten women from the Niètaga group are married. On average they are 35 years of age with three children, and all live in traditional households in the Dioni neighborhood of Konobougou, in the Baouréli prefecture of the 4th administrative region of Mali. These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, such as food condiments, cereals, soap, potatoes, dried fish, etc. Having fully repaid their four previous loans, the women from the Niètaga group are now requesting a fifth group loan. They intend to use it to buy three tons of cereal (beans, millet, corn, fonio), and packages of food condiments. They mainly get their supplies from local producers. They then sell their products in Dioni and at the Konobougou market, in general for cash, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 17,500 FCFA each, which will be used to bolster their working capital and contribute to family expenses regarding food, children’s education and healthcare.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various goods

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en: Mrs. Chhan N. has been a local tailor for years and also sews at home for a local factory. Additional family income is provided by her husband, who works as a building foreman. The couple has been married many years and is blessed with a child who is a student in class 8.  Chhan N. is requesting a loan to order clothing in bulk from industry that she will sew into furniture for sale. This will provide her with extra income in order to ensure a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To order clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Saroeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Saroeun K. is a villager who lives in Phnum Lonteah village, Takeo province. She is 55 years old and a widow with two children, one of whom is a grocery seller while the other one is farmer. She is a farmer who owns a 2.5-hectare field to cultivate rice.

Mrs. Saroeun K. is now requesting 2,000,000 KHR from AMK to buy a cow for breeding, and the rest of the loan she will use to buy fertilizer, pesticide and to hire farm laborers to support her farming.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Sabati Group

texts.fr:
Les dix femmes du groupe Sabati  sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Dioni de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments (huiles maggies), de céréales, du savon, des tubercules, du poisson etc.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Sabati sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, deux tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs), des colis des variétés de condiments alimentaires (des épices et un fût d’huile alimentaire).
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes à Dioni et au marché de Konobougou, généralement au comptant, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
All ten women from the Sabati group are married. On average they are 32 years of age with two children, and all live in traditional households in the Dioni neighborhood of Konobougou, in the Baouréli prefecture of the 4th administrative region of Mali. These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, such as food condiments (Maggi vegetable oil), cereals, soap, tubers, fish, etc. Having fully repaid their four previous loans, the women from the Sabati group are now requesting a fifth group loan. They intend to use it to buy two tons of cereal (beans, millet, corn), and packages of various food condiments (spices and a barrel of vegetable oil). They mainly get their supplies from local producers. They then sell their products in Dioni and at the Konobougou market, in general for cash, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA each, which will be used to bolster their working capital and contribute to family expenses regarding food, children’s education and healthcare.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various goods

loans.name: Shohida

texts.ru: Содикова Шохида проживает в районе Шахринав. Возраст, 38 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж, на заработках в России. Сама Шохида занимается растениеводством. Она более 5 лет выращивает пшеницу. До этого Шохида преподовала в средней школе. У нее высшее образование. Кредит берет для закупа семян. Она на полученные деньги хочет купить качественные семена. Весной посеить и получить хороший урожай.
texts.en:
Shohida S. lives in the Shahrinav district. She is 38 years old, married and has 3 children. Her husband is working in Russia. Shohida is involved in agriculture. She has been growing wheat for over 5 years. Previously, Shohida taught at a secondary school. She has a higher education. Shohida is requesting this loan for the purchase of seeds. She wants to use the money to buy quality seeds, plant them in the spring and get a good harvest.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Adebiyi

texts.en: Adebiyi is 37 years old and married with two children. His wife also works to support their home. For a long time, Adebiyi has been in the business of renting plastic chairs and tables to people in his community, and he hopes to expand his business in the future. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction with his customers. Adebiyi hopes for a loan amount of NGN 80,000 to purchase more plastic tables and chairs. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastic tables and chairs

loans.name: Thou

texts.en:
Mrs. Thou O. is a villager who lives in Pongro village, Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Mao Em, are farmers who own a 2-hectare field where they cultivate rice. Aside from farming, her husband is also a duck breeder who earns a small income to support his family.
                                           
Now is the dry season, so Mrs. Thou O. needs a loan from AMK to buy a water machine, fertilizer and pesticide to support her farm. She is 56 years old and the mother of two children, who are students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy a water machine, fertilizer, pesticide

loans.name: Teriya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept membres du groupe Teriya sont majoritairement des femmes mariées (6 mariées et une veuve). Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier Noukoula de la ville de Konobougou, préfecture de Baouréli, quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers essentiellement l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires et  des céréales.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les 4 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe  Teriya  sont à leur  5 prêt solidaire.
Elles comptent utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 4 tonnes de céréales (haricot mil, maïs, fonio, riz) et  plusieurs variétés de condiments alimentaires. 
Elles s’approvisionnent essentiellement sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes et effectuent leurs ventes à Noukoula et au marché de Konobougou, au comptant en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 17.000FCFA qui servira à étoffer leur fonds de commerce et subvenir aux dépenses ayant trait à la nourriture, à la scolarité des enfants et à la santé.
texts.en:
The majority of the seven members of the Teriya group are married (six married and one widow). They are on average 40 years old with three children and they all live in traditional families in the Noukoula district of the town of Konobougo, which lies in the "prefecture" of Baouréli, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. These women got to know each other through relatives and trade various products, essentially buying and selling condiments and cereals. Having repaid four previous loans without incident, the women in the Teriya group are on their 5th group loan. They are planning to use this new loan to buy 4 tons of cereal (beans, millet, corn, fonio, rice) and several varieties of condiments. They get their supplies principally from local producers and wholesalers and they sell their goods in Noukoula and on the market in Konobougou, for cash and on credit, to a customer base made up of both women and men. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 17,000 FCFA each, which will be used to boost their working capital and to cover expenses relating to food, their children's schooling and health.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various articles

loans.name: Wilson

texts.en:
Wilson is 60 years old and married with six grown children, who are between the ages of 18 and 30. He is a dairy farmer near Litein in Western Kenya. He's been farming for 20 years and is able to employ two people. He sells his milk through the Kenya Cooperative Creameries and also earns income from small-scale farming of tea and coffee. He says that the main challenges to his business are lack of funds to expand his business and a lack of education on how to keep quality animals and prevent the diseases that affect them.

He requested this first loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 45,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the added dairy cow will mean more income for his family. He gives his thanks to Juhudi Kilimo for the loan and for teaching him more about dairy farming. In the future, he would like to produce up to sixty liters of milk a day and purchase more farm land on which to keep an extra dairy cow.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sami

texts.en: Sami, 41 years old and married with 3 children, has worked as a car painter since 1982.  During his lengthy time in this occupation, he has gained a large number of clients asking for his painting services. He's thankful for his work, as it has allowed him over the years to improve,his living situation. Today, Sami is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy a used car that he can repair and then resell at a good profit.

loans.use: To buy a used car at a good price to repair and resell

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Les  5 femmes du groupe  Tièssiri, toutes mariées,  ont en moyenne  30 ans, 2 enfants et vivent  toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Konobougou une des sous préfectures de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, de l’habillement,  des tubercules, des fruits et légumes, du poisson fumé et séché etc. Elles font, en plus,  de la teinture et  de la restauration comme activités secondaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  6 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Tièssiri sont à leur  septième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter,  des paniers de poissons fumés et séchés, des  paquets de condiments alimentaires (tels les tomates fraîches,  les oignons, les sels de cuisine, les feuilles vertes), deux douzaines de complets pour enfants et quelques chargements de charrettes en  fruits. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Mopti (la cinquième région administrative du Mali) en poissons, auprès des producteurs et grossistes pour les autres articles. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes à domicile, au marché et dans les foires environnantes de Konobougou, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women in the Tièssiri group are all married with an average age of 30 and an average of two children; they all live in traditional extended families in Konobougou, one of the sub-prefectures of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women got to know each other through neighbors and relatives and they trade various articles, purchasing and selling for instance condiments, clothing, tubers, fruit and vegetables, smoked and dried fish etc.. Having repaid their six previous loans without any problems, the women in Tièssiri group are on their seventh group loan, which will be used to buy baskets of smoked and dried fish, packets of condiments (such as fresh tomatoes, onions, kitchen salt, green leaves), two dozen outfits for children and several barrowfuls of fruit. They get their supplies of fish in Mopti (the fifth administrative region of Mali) and the other articles from producers and wholesalers. They sell their goods at home, on the market and at the fairs in the surroundings of Konobougou, for cash and on credit, to a customer base made up of both women and men. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA each which will be used for expenses relating to health, food and school fees; the rest will be reinvested in their business.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various articles

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe  Djiguisseme ont en moyenne  41 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Bouwere dans la sous-préfecture de Konobougou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers tels l’achat vente de condiments alimentaires, du sucre, du poisson séché, des tubercules et des fruits et légumes. En plus du commerce elles font de temps à autres de la friandise et des galettes à base de mil. 
Après avoir correctement remboursés les  3 prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des  paquets de condiments alimentaires, des poissons séchés,  une grande quantité de fruits et légumes et patates douces. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (capitale du Mali), Mopti et sur place auprès des producteurs et grossistes. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes, à Bouwere, au marché de Konobougou ville et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 10.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture,  aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women from the Djiguisseme group are on average 41 years old with two children, and all live in traditional extended families in Bouwere, in the Konobougou sous-prefecture (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). These women got to know each other through family ties and are retailers of various goods, such as food condiments, sugar, dried fish, tubers, fruit and vegetables. From time to time they also prepare millet-based sweets and wafers. Having fully repaid their three previous loans, the women from the Djiguisseme group are now requesting a fourth group loan. They intend to use it to buy packages of food condiments, dried fish, a large quantity of fruit and vegetables, and sweet potatoes. They mainly get their supplies from Bamako (the capital of Mali), from Mopti and from local producers and wholesalers. They then sell their products in Bouwere, at the central Konobougou market and in surrounding market fairs, retail for cash and credit, to a customer base of both women and men. They hope to achieve average monthly earnings of 10,000 FCFA each, which will be used for expenses related to healthcare, food, and schooling costs. The remainder will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various goods

loans.name: Ayawoavi

texts.en: Ayawoavi B. is a 48 year-old single mother of one child. She works in the Adidogomé district of Lomé, Togo selling pharmaceuticals to her community. She began this business in 2007 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to restock her shelves full of the pharmaceuticals that are in high demand. This loan will help support Ms. B.’s family and keep her customers in good health.

loans.use: To buy more stock of pharmaceuticals.

loans.name: Lutfulo

texts.ru: Хабибов Лутфуло проживает в районе Шахринав. Возраст, 41 год. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Лутфулло более 15 лет занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот у себя дома. В этом ему помогают дети. Кредит берет для закупа скота. Этот бизнес приносит ему доход. Он один содержает семью.
texts.en:
Lutfulo H. lives in the Shahrinav district. He is 41 years old, married and has 2 children. His wife is a homemaker. Lutfulo has been involved in animal husbandry for over 15 years. He breeds livestock at home. His children help him with this business. Lutfulo is requesting the loan for the purchase of livestock. This business brings him income. He is the sole provider for his family.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Ren

texts.en: Mrs. Ren U. is a 29 year-old married woman who lives in Prey Run village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Art Eng, are farmers who own a plot of land on which they cultivate rice. The couple has a child who is too young to study or work. Aside from farming, her husband is also a well digger but can earn only a little income to support his family. (Her husband is on the right of the picture.) Although they try to work hard, they still cannot earn enough money to support their family. Thus, Mrs. Ren U. is now requesting for 6,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy four piglets to breed. With this loan, Mrs. Ren U. hopes to increase her income to improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy four piglets.

loans.name: Mélé Juliette

texts.fr: A. Mélé Juliette est née le 30 juillet 1978 à Lomé au Togo, pays voisin du Bénin.  Mariée à HONTONWAKOU Aristide, un chauffeur, Mélé Juliette est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont encore à sa charge.  La famille vit ensemble au quartier Avotrou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Mélé Juliette a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Mélé Juliette mène comme activité la vente de tissus et des chaussures à son domicile. Parallèlement à cette activité, Mélé Juliette vend des savons, des bonbons, et des conserves en boîtes.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé que Mélé Juliette s’approvisionne.  Mélé Juliette a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Mélé Juliette sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux satisfaire ses clients.  Elle ambitionne plus tard construire une boutique dans laquelle elle pourra bien exposer ses marchandises.
texts.en:
Mélé Juliette A. was born July 30, 1978 in Lomé in Togo, a country adjacent to Benin. Married to Aristide HONTONWAKOU, a driver, Mélé Juliette is the mother of three children, all having had schooling, and of whom two are still under her care. Mélé Juliette has herself attended school up to secondary level. The family lives together in the Avotrou neighborhood of Cotonou, economic capital of Benin. The couple shares family expenses. To meet her needs Mélé Juliette has been selling pieces of fabric and shoe wear from her home. As a side business, she also retails soap, candy, and canned food. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and from Lomé. Mélé Juliette has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she repaid in full. She is now requesting another loan, to strengthen her business and increase customer satisfaction. Her ambition is to eventually build a shop where she can appealingly display her products.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric, sho wear and various products

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 32 years old and married with six children, five of whom are attending school. He is a farmer near Litein in Western Kenya. He's been farming for three years and is already able to employ two people. He sells his milk through the Kenya Cooperative Creameries and also earns some income from small-scale farming of cash crops. He says that the main challenges to his business are the market for milk and price saturation for it.

He previously completed a loan from Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 20,000 and requested this loan for Kes. 50,000 to purchase and insure another dairy cow. He says that the extra income he'll earn will raise his family's standard of living and help him pay his children's school fees. In the future, he would like to have at least three grade cows that can produce at least 15 liters a day each.

Thomas thanks Juhudi Kilimo for the work they are doing to improve the living standards of the poor.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sok Kea

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok Kea E. is a villager who lives in Ampil Lech village in Takeo province. She sells groceries in a small store she owns. Her husband, Mr. ChhE. Yin, is a silk weaver who can earn only a little income to support his family.
    
Mrs. Sok Kea E. now is requesting 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to buy more silks to support her husband's business. The rest of the loan she will use to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding. This loan will help increase her income and improve her family's living conditions. 

This couple has three children, two of whom are students in the public school while the youngest one is just two years old. Her husband is on the right of the picture.

loans.use: To buy more silks for weaving.

loans.name: Idrissa

texts.fr:
Né vers 1980 à Ségou, Monsieur Idrissa S. est comptable de formation, marié à une épouse et père d’un enfant. Il vit chez son père  dans le quartier Darsalam I  de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).  
Monsieur S.  fut contraint  avec le décès de son grand frère qui aidait son père à  gérer  leur pharmacie, d’arrêter  son stage, pour remplacer son frère défunt au niveau de la pharmacie. 
Les médicaments faisant parties des besoins de première nécessitée dans nos pays sous-développés, il est très sollicité par ses clients et sa notoriété est sans égale à Koutiala. 
Pour augmenter  son stock de produits pharmaceutiques, il décida de faire recours à l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son 1er prêt  individuel. 
Monsieur  S. compte acheter différents produits pharmaceutiques (médicaments) avec ce prêt. 
Il s’approvisionne  auprès des dépositaires agrées  de Bamako (capitale du Mali). Il  vend  les médicaments, tous les jours au niveau de la pharmacie sise au grand marché de Koutiala,  à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes, généralement  au comptant. 
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200.000FCFA qu’il envisage utiliser pour rembourser l’échéance du prêt, utiliser  le reste pour  acheter  de la nourriture et investir dans ses activités.
Il ambitionne solliciter un financement plus important  qui pourra lui permettre d’agrandir non seulement sa pharmacie et par conséquent augmenter son chiffre d’affaire lui permettant  ainsi d’améliorer sa condition de vie.
texts.en:
Born around 1980 in Ségou, Mr. Idrissa S. is a trained accountant, married to one wife and the father of one child. He lives with his father in the Darsalam I district of the Koutiala prefecture (in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. S. was forced by the death of his older brother, who helped his father manage their pharmacy, to abandon his training. He replaced his deceased brother at the pharmacy. Medicine is one of the primary needs in our underdeveloped nation; he is very much in demand and his reputation is without equal in Koutiala. In order to increase his pharmaceutical stocks, he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso, through which he is requesting his first individual loan. Mr. S. plans to buy various pharmaceutical products (medicines) with this loan. He gets his supplies from approved agents in Bamako, the capital of Mali. He sells medicine everyday at the pharmacy located in the main market of Koutiala, to a clientele of men and women who generally pay in cash. He plans to clear a monthly profit of 200,000 FCFA which he plans to use to repay the loan, and to use the rest to buy food and invest in his business. His goal is to seek more substantial financing which will allow him to not only improve his business and therefore his turnover, but also his quality of life.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase medicine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying cocoa

loans.name: Agossè Félicité

texts.fr: D. Agossè Félicité est née vers 1979 à Savalou, mais vit depuis neuf ans au quartier Lom-Nava à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à BOTON Marcellin, un technicien en BTP, Agossè Félicité est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Agossè Félicité vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Agossè Félicité n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire et a appris ensuite la coiffure.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Agossè Félicité vend des tissus et des glacières par le système de distribution. Agossè Félicité exerce cette activité depuis trois ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et au marché Missèbo à Cotonou. Agossè Félicité a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Agossè Félicité désire élever le niveau de son activité afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients, mais elle manque suffisamment de moyens financiers pour y arriver.  C’est la raison pour laquelle Agossè Félicité sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.  Elle ambitionne plus tard ouvrir un salon de coiffure bien équipé.
texts.en:
Agossè Félicité D. was born around 1979 in Savalou, but has lived for nine years in the Lom-Nava district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Marcellin Boton, a technician at BTP, Agossè Félicité is the mother of three children, all of whom attend school and are in her care. Agossè Félicité lives with her husband and her children. Together the couple shares the family responsibilities. Agossè Félicité only attended primary school, and then she learned hairstyling. To meet her needs, she sells fabric and coolers through the distribution system. She has been doing this type of work for three years and she gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin, and at the Missèbo market in Contonou. Agossè Félicité has already taken out two loans through ALIDé which she has fully repaid. Agossè Félicité wishes to raise the level of her business in order to meet the demands her clients, but she lacks the funds to make this happen. It is for this reason that she is requesting a third loan through ALIDé. Her ambition for the future is to open a well equipped hairstyling salon.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase fabric and coolers

loans.name: Silvana

texts.en:
Silvana is an 18-year-old single woman. She learned hairdressing in a beauty academy and she started working at the same time in 2006. Starting 1 year ago, after graduating, she opened her own business in her home where she presents hairdressing services in addition to selling beauty products to her clients. 

In the future, Silvana wishes to open her own beauty salon, and she is working hard to make this dream come true. Today, Silvana is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to buy new beauty products and hair accessories and supplies to satisfy the needs of her clients.

loans.use: buy new beauty products and hair accessories and supplies

loans.name: Toke

texts.en:
Toke is a hard-working woman, and she is friendly. She sells sarongs and shoes at retail prices to her customers. She hawks her goods within her community in Ibadan. She hopes to own a stall in the future. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. 

To support their home, her husband sells tires. Toke has 3 children. Her eldest child is 20 years old while the youngest child is 5 years old. Her children are schooling and this makes her happy. She duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Nhy

texts.en:
Mrs. Nhy C. is 42 years old and lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Samon Yin, are farmers who own a two-hectare field on which they cultivate rice. Mr. Samon Yin (who is pictured on the left) is also a farm laborer who can receive only a little salary to support his family. This couple has two children, one of whom is accountant in the private company while the other one is student in the local school. 

Mrs. Nhy C. is now requesting 2,000,000 Riel from AMK to purchase a water machine to support her farming and a cow for breeding.

loans.use: To purchase a water machine and a cow.

loans.name: Sanata

texts.fr:
Madame Sanata Traoré est âgée de 27 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille polygame  avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la préfecture de Koutiala (région de Sikasso). 
Dû  à des raisons sociales, elle n’a pas pu continuer  les études.  Très tôt elle s’intéressa aux  activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman. Nantie d’une expérience de 6 ans d’apprentissage, elle mena plusieurs activités, mais finit par opter pour  l’achat et la vente des tissus et  des chaussures. 
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle en quantité et en qualité, elle décida de  faire recours à  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant  1 an. Elle est à son deuxième prêt individuel  après avoir correctement remboursé le premier. 
 Avec ce  financement  elle compte acheter, 10 complets de tissus brodés,  5 pièces de pagnes wax et 20 paires de chaussures. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé  (capitale de la république du Togo) et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala de façon ambulante et à domicile, à une clientèle composée  de femmes et hommes ,  au comptant ou à crédit.  
Elle compte  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000 FCFA  qu’elle envisage utiliser pour  le remboursement des intérêts du prêt, participer aux dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.
texts.en:
Ms Sanata Traoré, aged 27, is married and the mother of two children. She lives in a polygamous family with her husband, her cowife and their children in the neighborhood of Hamdallaye in the prefecture of Koutiala (region of Sikasso). Social reasons prevented her from continuing her studies. She took very early an interest in income generating activities with her mother. She enjoyed a 6-year-long learning experience which showed her several activities, and in the end she opted for buying and selling fabrics and shoes. To meet the demand of her customers, both in terms of quantity and quality, Sanata decided a year ago to turn to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is her second individual loan. She repaid her first loan on schedule. She wants to use this loan to buy 10 embroidered suits, 5 lengths of wax pagnes (brightly colored African print cloth) and 20 pairs of shoes. Sanata gets her supplies in Lomé, the capital of the Republic of Togo, and sells them, for cash or credit, in the city of Koutiala, both hawking and from home, to a clientele made up of women and men. Sanata expects to make a monthly profit of 75,000 CFA francs which she will use to pay the interests of her loan and help to provide for the daily needs of the family, as well as reinvest in other income generating activities.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and shoes

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: K. Nicole est née le 4 décembre 1965 à Tori-Bossito, mais vit depuis cinq ans au quartier Kpondéhou à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.   Mariée à TOGONOU Nourou, un fonctionnaire, Nicole est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés.  Nicole vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Nicole a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Nicole vend des tissus et des sous-vêtements par le système de distribution.  Nicole vend de façon secondaire, des bijoux. Nicole exerce cette activité depuis 12 ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Nicole a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Nicole sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Nicole K. was born on 4th December 1965 in Tori-Bossito, but has lived for the past five years in the Kpondéhou district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Nourou TOGONOU, a civil servant, Nicole has two children who are both at school. She lives with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Nicole went to school up until secondary level. In order to provide for her needs, she sells fabric and underwear through the distribution system. She also has a secondary activity selling jewelry. Nicole has been exercising this activity for twelve years and gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She has already had two loans from ALIDé which she has paid without any problem. She is applying for a third loan from ALIDé in order to strengthen her business and satisfy client demand more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and underwear

loans.name: Laet

texts.en:
Mrs. Laet K. is 25 years old and lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She is married with two children who are twins and too young to study or work. She and her husband, Mr. Sochea Sao, are farmers who own a two-hectare field on which they cultivate rice. Mr. Sochea Sao (pictured on the right) also owns a rice milling machine that he rents out to other farmers to use. He can earn only a small income to support his family.

Mrs. Laet K. is now requesting 2,000,000 Riel to purchase more rice to mill and resell and piglets and pig food for pig breeding. This loan will help to increase her income and improve her family living too.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food .

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 47 years old and married with eight children between the ages of five and twenty, seven of whom are attending school. He is a dairy farmer near Litein in Western Kenya and has been farming for twelve years. He sells his milk through the Kenya Cooperative Creameries and also earns income from small-scale farming of coffee and tea. He says that the main challenges to his business are diseases that affect his livestock and lack of sufficient feed.

He requested this first loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 40,000 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the added dairy cow will increase his family's income and that, in the future, he would like to produce over fifty liters of milk a day and construct a modern dairy unit that can keep up to five cows.

He thanks Juhudi Kilimo for this loan and says that he will request further funding from Juhudi after he completes this loan.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin sells groceries like laundry soap, bathing soap, toothbrushes, and beverages. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves her business because of the opportunity to meet one-on-one with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She is a hard-working woman. She opens her stall daily to sell her goods. She is 40 years old and married with 2 children. Her children are making progress in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Peace

texts.en:
Peace is 29 years old, married with two children.  Peace and her family live in the Gasabo district where she operates a business selling clothes.  This is her seventh successful year in this business, which she starts from early in the morning until 6 PM every day.
	
Peace is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing some other attractive clothing styles for sale as well as additional sizes and colors.  With this loan, Peace hopes to attract more customers to her shop and hopefully earn more profits in the process.  This, in turn will allow her and her devoted husband to create other sources of income through reinvesting in the same business in various areas.  With this reinvestment, they will help the people from their community by employing them.

loans.use: Additional styles of clothing for sale

loans.name: Bukola

texts.en: Bukola sells groceries like laundry soap, bathing soap, toothbrushes and beverages. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She loves her business because of the opportunity to meet one-on-one with her customers. She hopes for the loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She is a hard-working woman. She opens her stall daily to sell her goods. She is 31 years old and married with 2 children. Her children are making progress in school. Her husband is a teacher and he also supports their home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Uljon

texts.ru: Гулова Улжон проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 42 года. Замужем, имеет 6 детей. Улжон более 5 лет занимается животноводством. Она разводит крупно- рогатый скот у себя дома. В этой деятельности ей помогает муж. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество. Так как сейчас цены на животных понизились Улжон хочет купить бычка и весной продать по более выгодной цене.
texts.en:
Uljon G. lives in the Yavan district. She is 42 years old, married and has 6 children. Uljon has been involved in animal husbandry for over 5 years. She breeds cattle at home. Her husband helps her with this business. Uljon is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle in order to increase its quantity. Because livestock prices now decreased, Uljon wants to buy a bull and resell it in the spring at a more profitable price.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Ghassan

texts.en:
Ghassan is a 31-year-old single man living with his two parents. He has been working as an event organizer for the past 12 years. He organizes all kinds of parties, ceremonies, weddings, and other speciA. events and he's very happy with his occupation. He has always tried to be up-to-date and to get all the new ideas and organizationA. preparation. He is the only provider for his parents and he takes good care of them. 

Today, Ghassan is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 to purchase additionA. equipment and hosting clothes before the summer season so he will be in demand with his clients and meet their requirements.

loans.use: purchase additional equipment and hosting clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en: Mostafa is a 21-year-old single man. He has been working as an electrician for the past 5 years. With his business income, he helps his father support the household. Working on a freelance basis, he manages part of house-building projects in his town and its surroundings. With the help of the loan requested, US$ 1,000, he can manage to expand his business by buying tools to better satisfy the needs of the market and increase his business to earn a good income.

loans.use: buying tools

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying millet and soy beans

loans.name: Amadou Fall

texts.fr: Monsieur Amadou Diène est sociétaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC Camberene depuis juillet 2001. Il habite dans la même localité et a déjà rembourse 4 prêts ante rieurs.Il est marie et père de 3 enfants. Il exerce l’activité de tailleur depuis plus de17 ans.IL confectionne, expose pour la vente et reçoit frequemment des commandes qu’il essaie de satisfaire. Les périodes les plus intéressantes de son activiste sont les périodes de fêtes. Il sollicite un crédit de 300 000 frs pour l’achat de tissus et de fournitures de couture pour accroitre son offre. L’augmentation de sa marge bénéficiaire lui permettra de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Amadou Diène has been a member of the U-IMCEC in Camberene since July of 2001. He lives in the vicinity and has already repaid four previous loans. He is married and the father of three children. He has worked as a tailor for more than 17 years. He manufactures and displays his clothing for sale, frequently receiving orders which he tries to fulfill. His most profitable times are during holidays. He is requesting a loan of 300,000 FRS for the purchase of fabric and sewing equipment to augment his supply. The increase in his profit margin will better enable him to meet the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: investment

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Altantsetseg is a 53 year-old widow who lives and works in Ulaanbaatar. She lives with her two children and a grand-daughter, and is also raising her two nephews. Her brother died in 2007 and Altantsetseg took in his children, ages 11 and 13 years. 

For the past several years, she has run a little bookstand that she moves from place to place depending where people are. She has sold books at the Naadam field, as well as the children’s park. She also sells at bus stops. Last fall her son Turbat (who is 25) built her a little store from which to sell her books. With a loan, Altantsetseg wants to buy writing instruments, like pens and pencils, so that she can sell them along with the books to make a little more money. Because her husband died several years ago, the family depends on her little shop. 

Altantsetseg is a little deaf but that doesn’t affect her in any way.  She is a very intelligent and clever person. She lives for those she provides for and her goal in life is to raise them to be good people.

loans.use: To purchase writing instruments to sell along with the books.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying electronics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a fridge to prepare fruit juices, ice and fresh water

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip renders computer services and he also sells rechargeable phone cards at retail prices to his customers. With these combined businesses, he hopes to make his undertaking sustainable. He is a young, hard-working man and he is determined to excel in business. He loves his business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He hopes for the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. 

Philip is 28 years old and single, without children. He hopes to get married and have children very soon. He is itching for expansion in his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Numonjon's Group

texts.en:
Married and a father of two children, Numonjon was born on May 12, 1967 in Dushanbe. Coming from an area where cattle-raising is popular, Numonjon has been selling cattle since 2001. He buys them in his village from the farmers who raise them and then sells them at the markets. As his business capital is limited, Numonjon buys just a few and then after he sells those, he returns to buy more. 

Today he would like to expand his business by increasing his capital so that he can maximize his profits. For this reason, Numonjon is requesting a loan of $3000 to purchase young cattle. This will be his second loan with IMON International, and his evaluation shows he is qualified to receive the loan.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase young cattle to expand his business.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda H. is 52 years old and lives with her spouse. She works every day, starting very early in the morning so that she can get ahead and achieve her goal of having her three children successfully enter and finish school. Her business is located in the central market of Dushanbe city and she sells clothes for kids. Thanks to the support of her spouse and her own effort, Mavluda was able to expand her business, which began with little inventory and in a small space and now has a bigger space and a large clientele. With the loan of 5000 Somoni, Mavluda will buy a greater variety of clothing styles, for a variety of occasions, and a few specific requests of her customers. 

Support this woman of much strength and courage to keep working.

loans.use: To buy new clothing for kids in order to increase her range of goods.

loans.name: Rachel

texts.en: Rachel Y. sells stationery at Elmina. She is a single mother of four children with a senior high school education. Rachel has been selling stationery for some time now. She is responsible for paying her children's school fees and the family's utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more stationery and other office supplies for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more stationery and other office supplies.

loans.name: Gulinoz

texts.ru: Хушиева Гулиноз проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 39 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Гулиноз более 5 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она вместе с мужем продает одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота. Она хочет отдельно открыть свою торговую точку и расширить свой бизнес.
texts.en:
Gulinoz H. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 39 years old, married and has 4 children. Gulinoz has been involved in retail sales at the market for over 5 years. Together with her husband, she sells clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover. Gulinoz wants to open a separate retail outlet and expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Akram

texts.en:
Akram M. is 32 years old. Together with his wife, he has 4 children. Akram is an experienced bread baker. He has been baking for more than eleven years and his wife helps him with his business. Having many customers, Akram is selling the majority of his products just from his place. However, he is also running a trading place in the central local market where he sells lepeshka (the national bread). Now Akram is requesting $1375 to purchase flour wholesale for his business. Akram is grateful for all supporting him and promises to manage the loan with accuracy.

loans.use: To purchase flour wholesale to bake lepeshka (the national bread).

loans.name: Bozor

texts.en:
N. Bozor is a 50-year-old married man who owns a small farm. He is a hard-working man who has fought to provide for his family and educate his children, who today are working adults thanks to his example. 

Bozor has been running the business of raising and selling cattle. He has 27 years of experience in this field. Since cattle raising and selling is a profitable business, Bozor has become a very successful businessman in a very short period. He works very hard and spends all his time with his animals, cleaning them, feeding and pasturing. 

Now Bozor wants to expand his business and buy more cattle. So he applied for a loan of $2500 USD. Bozor thanks all lenders for their support.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: Paullina

texts.en:
Paullina sells foodstuffs like dried peppers, melons, palm oil, groundnut oil, tomato paste, and more at one of the local markets in Benin City, Nigeria. She runs this business to make sure there is food on her table and to take care of other financial needs at home like payment of the children's school fees, buying of school books for her children, etc. She has been able to support her family and play a vital role in the family and that gives her joy in running the business. 

Paullina hopes to save part of her income to purchase a plot of land where she can build a house and rent it out, as this will also serve as another income-generating source as the business improves. 

She is a member of LAPO Microfinance; she hopes to expand the size of her business in future. She is requesting the loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. Paullina is 45 years old, married with 5 children, and they are doing well. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Astou

texts.fr:
Mademoiselle Astou F. est une jeune femme de 22 ans .Elle habite dans la localité de Camberene et est societaire de la caisse de l’U-IMCEC depuis 2006. Elle a déjà rembourse 2 prêts antérieurs au sein de l’institution. Elle gère  un local ou elle vend des effets de toilette. Mademoiselle F. exerce cette activité depuis plus de 10 ans. Elle sollicite un crédit de 300 000 frs en vue de renforcer et diversifier  son stock  de produits. Ainsi elle pourra élargira sa clientèle et augmenter ses bénéfices. L’évolution positive de son activité lui permettra de mieux supporter ses besoins sociaux et personnels.
-
texts.en:
Miss Astou F. is a young lady who is 22 years old. She lives in the village of Camberebe and has been a shareholder-member of the U-IMCEC (a Senegalese mutual savings and loans institution association) savings institution since 2006. She has already repaid two previous loans from the institution. She manages a shop where she sells toiletries. Miss F. has been carrying out this activity for more than ten years. She is applying for a loan of 300,000 francs in order to strengthen and diversify her stock of products. This will allow her to enlarge her customer base and increase her profits. The positive development of her business will enable her to provide for her personal and social needs more easily. -

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of funds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of hair extensions, wigs, and other materials
